notes.title: Schools of Psychology: Structuralism, Functionalism, Behaviorism, Gestalt, Cognitive, Humanistic
notes.content: Contrast early schools (Structuralism—Titchener, introspection; Functionalism—James, adaptive functions) with Behaviorism (Watson/Skinner), Gestalt (perceptual organization), Cognitive revolution (information processing), and Humanistic (Rogers/Maslow). Map typical exam prompts that ask for comparisons, criticisms, and legacy in modern psychology.
keyTakeaways: Know methods: introspection vs. experiment vs. observation.
Gestalt's 'the whole is other than the sum of parts'.
Cognitive perspective integrates biology, memory, language; humanistic adds agency/values.

resources.title: OpenStax — Psychology 2e (Ch. 1)
resources.description: Free comprehensive intro text covering major schools

notes.title: Nervous System & Brain: CNS, PNS, Lobes, Endocrine links
notes.content: Outline CNS (brain, spinal cord) and PNS (somatic/autonomic—sympathetic vs parasympathetic). Brain lobes' core functions and high-yield nuclei. Endocrine system's role in behavior and stress responses.
keyTakeaways: CNS integrates; PNS relays—ANS controls involuntary responses.
Frontal: executive control; Temporal: audition/memory; Parietal: somatosensory; Occipital: vision.
Endocrine (pituitary, thyroid, adrenals) modulates arousal, metabolism, stress.

notes.title: Classical Conditioning (Pavlov) — Core Mechanisms & Applications
notes.content: Unconditioned stimulus (US) → Unconditioned response (UR); pair neutral stimulus → becomes conditioned stimulus (CS) producing conditioned response (CR). Generalization, discrimination, extinction, spontaneous recovery.
keyTakeaways: Learning via associations; timing and contingency matter.
Therapy links: exposure, systematic desensitization foundations.

notes.title: Operant Conditioning (Thorndike → Skinner): Reinforcement & Punishment
notes.content: Behavior shaped by consequences. Law of Effect (Thorndike): satisfying outcomes strengthen S-R bonds; Skinner formalized reinforcement (positive/negative) and punishment with schedules (fixed/variable ratio/interval).
keyTakeaways: Reinforcement increases behavior; punishment decreases—be precise with terms.
Variable-ratio schedules produce high, steady responding (e.g., gambling).

notes.title: Observational/Social Learning — Bandura's Bobo Doll
notes.content: Learning via observation, modeling, vicarious reinforcement; cognition mediates behavior beyond simple conditioning.
keyTakeaways: Children imitate aggressive models; media implications.
Four processes: attention, retention, reproduction, motivation.

notes.title: Piaget's Cognitive Development — 4 Stages & Exam Applications
notes.content: Sensorimotor (object permanence), Preoperational (egocentrism), Concrete Operational (conservation), Formal Operational (abstract reasoning).
keyTakeaways: Order and ages are frequently tested.
Apply stages to education and parenting scenarios.

notes.title: Moral Development — Kohlberg vs. Gilligan
notes.content: Kohlberg's 3 levels/6 stages (justice-oriented reasoning) vs. Gilligan's ethics of care critique (context, relationships, care).
keyTakeaways: Contrast justice vs. care orientations; cultural/gender debate.
Scenario-based exam questions often test stage identification.

notes.title: Emotion Theories — James-Lange, Cannon-Bard, Schachter-Singer
notes.content: Physiology → emotion (James-Lange) vs. simultaneous (Cannon-Bard) vs. physiology + cognitive label (Schachter-Singer). Include appraisal and facial feedback add-ons.
keyTakeaways: Differentiate order of events and role of cognition.
Be ready for diagrammatic comparisons.

notes.title: Intelligence: Fluid vs. Crystallized; Multiple Intelligences; Major Tests
notes.content: Cattell-Horn: fluid (novel problem solving) vs. crystallized (acquired knowledge). Gardner's MI broadens domains (8–9 types). WAIS/WISC and Stanford-Binet as standardized IQ measures.
keyTakeaways: Distinguish CHC model vs. Gardner's MI (empirical debates).
Know what WAIS/WISC/SB5 measure and when each is used.

notes.title: Perception: Gestalt Laws & Depth Cues
notes.content: Gestalt principles (proximity, similarity, continuity, closure, symmetry) explain how we organize stimuli; depth perception via binocular and monocular cues.
keyTakeaways: Be able to apply a principle to a figure.
Monocular cues (linear perspective, texture gradient) are common MCQs.

notes.title: Motivation: Biological vs. Social Motives; Maslow's Hierarchy
notes.content: Differentiate biogenic (hunger, thirst) vs. sociogenic (achievement, affiliation, power) motives; integrate Maslow's needs and critiques.
keyTakeaways: Hierarchy is flexible; cultural/contextual modifiers exist.
Achievement motivation connects to workplace outcomes.

notes.title: Research Methods: Variables, Designs, Reliability & Validity
notes.content: Independent vs. dependent variables, experimental/quasi designs; reliability (test-retest, inter-rater, internal consistency) vs. validity (construct, criterion, content).
keyTakeaways: Reliability ≠ validity; both needed for sound measures.
Know threats to validity and how to control them.

notes.title: Ethics in Psychological Research: Belmont + APA Code
notes.content: Belmont principles (Respect, Beneficence, Justice) underpin IRB processes; APA Code operationalizes professional standards (confidentiality, consent, competence).
keyTakeaways: Link historical abuses to modern safeguards.
Apply principles to vignettes (e.g., deception, vulnerable populations).

notes.title: Psychological Testing: Standardization, Reliability & Validity
notes.content: Define standardized tests, norms, error; interpret reliability coefficients and validate tests for intended uses.
keyTakeaways: Always report intended purpose and population.
Misuse of tests is an ethical violation.

notes.title: Projective vs. Objective Tests (Rorschach, TAT, MMPI)
notes.content: Contrast projective techniques (ambiguous stimuli → projection) with objective inventories (standardized items/scales). Evaluate psychometrics and clinical utility.
keyTakeaways: Projectives face validity/reliability debates; use cautiously.
Objective tests (e.g., MMPI) have stronger norms and validity scales.

resources.title: PMC — Systematic review of projective techniques (2025)

notes.title: Major Disorders — Anxiety, Mood, Schizophrenia (high-yield DSM concepts)
notes.content: Recognize core DSM-5-TR criteria patterns (e.g., GAD's 6-month worry + 3+ symptoms), symptom clusters of depressive disorders, and schizophrenia positive/negative symptoms. Treatment overviews (CBT, medication).
keyTakeaways: Memorize hallmark features & differentials (panic vs. GAD vs. phobia).
Pair with evidence-based therapies (CBT first-line for many).

notes.title: Therapies — CBT & REBT (Evidence & Techniques)
notes.content: CBT (Beck): identify & restructure maladaptive cognitions; REBT (Ellis): dispute irrational beliefs (ABC model).
keyTakeaways: CBT is highly evidence-based across common disorders.
REBT emphasizes active disputation and philosophic change.

notes.title: Systematic Desensitization & Exposure
notes.content: Behavioral treatment (Wolpe) that pairs relaxation with graded exposure to feared stimuli; modern variants use in-vivo/imaginal/VR exposure.
keyTakeaways: Hierarchy building and relaxation training are exam staples.
Extends classical conditioning principles to therapy.

notes.title: Social Psychology: Obedience & Power of Situations
notes.content: Milgram's obedience experiments demonstrate compliance under authority; Stanford Prison Experiment highlights situational roles and ethical controversies.
keyTakeaways: Discuss ethics (consent, debrief, distress).
Modern critiques question methodology and interpretations.

notes.title: Attribution, Attitudes & Dissonance
notes.content: Attribution theories (Heider; Kelley's covariation model) explain person vs. situation causes. Cognitive dissonance (Festinger) drives attitude/behavior change.
keyTakeaways: Use consensus/consistency/distinctiveness triad for Kelley.
Dissonance reduction strategies (change belief, change behavior, add cognitions).

resources.title: Wiley chapter PDF — Malle (2022) Attribution Theories

notes.title: Emotional Intelligence (EI) — Goleman's Model & Evidence
notes.content: EI includes self-awareness, self-management, social awareness, and relationship management; relevance to leadership and health outcomes.
keyTakeaways: Differentiate EI models (ability vs. mixed).
Use in organizational settings with validated measures.

notes.title: Personality Theories & Assessment
notes.content: Psychoanalytic (Freud), Trait (Big Five), Humanistic (Rogers), Social-cognitive (Bandura). Link theories to assessment approaches and typical critiques.
keyTakeaways: Trait approach emphasizes stability and factor models.
Humanistic highlights self-concept; social-cognitive: reciprocal determinism.

notes.title: Sensation vs. Perception
notes.content: Differentiate sensory transduction from perceptual interpretation; determinants of perception include attention, context, expectations (top-down vs. bottom-up).
keyTakeaways: Exam MCQs frequently ask for examples of top-down effects.
Apply to illusions and reading tasks.

notes.title: Industrial/Organizational (I/O) Psychology Essentials
notes.content: Leadership, motivation at work, job satisfaction, organizational culture, stress & conflict, selection and assessment basics.
keyTakeaways: Tie reinforcement and goal-setting to productivity.
Leadership: transactional vs. transformational contrasts.

notes.title: Health Psychology — Stress, Coping, Social Support
notes.content: Biopsychosocial model; stress appraisal, coping strategies, role of social support in outcomes; behavior change frameworks.
keyTakeaways: Stress models (e.g., transactional) show appraisal's role.
Health behaviors linked to motivation/emotion content.

notes.title: Forensic Psychology — Eyewitness, Confessions, Law
notes.content: Memory fallibility, suggestibility, and lineup procedures; interrogation effects; expert testimony boundaries.
keyTakeaways: Reliability of eyewitness testimony is limited; emphasize procedures that reduce bias.
Ethical constraints in assessments for legal contexts.

notes.title: High-Yield Experiments & Critiques
notes.content: Milgram (obedience), Zimbardo (prison), Bandura (Bobo), Pavlov (conditioning), Skinner (operant), Piaget (conservation tasks). Include methodological critiques and modern replications/debates.
keyTakeaways: Always pair classic findings with ethical/method critiques.
Know DV/IV and sample/setting limits.

notes.title: CSS/FPSC Alignment & Topic Map
notes.content: Map your study to the FPSC CSS Psychology syllabus: nature/scope; biological bases; sensation/perception; learning/memory; motivation/emotion; assessment/testing; personality; intelligence; social influence/group dynamics; developmental; abnormal/clinical; I/O; health; forensic.
keyTakeaways: Use the official syllabus as the spine; plug in the above notes under each heading.
Practice with past MCQs/long questions on repeated patterns (Piaget, conditioning, emotion theories, DSM basics).
